top_categories.workout_context: Paris to Ancaster’s rail trail, farm lanes demands rapid power changes — surge over obstacles, settle on smoother sections, repeat for hours.
Racing Paris to Ancaster isn’t just fitness — it’s pacing, fueling, and executing when conditions deteriorate. This workout practices the race itself.
Paris to Ancaster’s multi-surface chaos—rail trails to mud chutes in one race drains energy reserves faster than the distance suggests — durability training bridges the gap.
Paris to Ancaster’s multi-surface chaos—rail trails to mud chutes in one race and competitive field demand explosive aerobic capacity — the ability to respond to surges without blowing up.
Critical power determines how long you can sustain above-threshold efforts at Paris to Ancaster — a higher CP means more time in the red before failure.
Paris to Ancaster rewards athletes who can hold sustained power without blowing up — threshold is the engine that drives everything above Zone 2.
Short, violent efforts are unavoidable at Paris to Ancaster — climbs demanding 2-minute maximal efforts, surges to close gaps, attacks on multi-surface chaos—rail trails to mud chutes in one race.
Over-unders train the lactate clearance you’ll need at Paris to Ancaster when surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding hard.
The G-Spot zone (88–92% FTP) is where you’ll spend the hardest sustained miles of Paris to Ancaster. Make this intensity feel like home.
Every session at Paris to Ancaster intensity builds on this aerobic foundation — the endurance base is the soil everything else grows in.
Cadence efficiency makes every pedal stroke at Paris to Ancaster count — smooth technique reduces muscular fatigue over long distances.
The varied gradients at Paris to Ancaster reward climbing adaptability — knowing when to sit, when to stand, and when to switch.

race_overlay.heat: April in Paris to Ancaster, Ontario, Canada can bring heat. Complete 3–4 heat exposure sessions in the final 2 weeks before Paris to Ancaster. Increase sodium intake 48 hours before race day.
race_overlay.nutrition: Target 40–60g carbs/hour for Paris to Ancaster’s 62 miles. Front-load calories in the first half. One bottle per hour minimum, more in heat.
race_overlay.terrain: Highly technical terrain at Paris to Ancaster demands practice on similar surfaces. Ride multi-surface chaos—rail trails to mud chutes in one race at race-day cadence weekly. Expect: rail trail, farm lanes, mud chutes. Practice cornering, descending, and power delivery on unstable surfaces. Dial in tire pressure before race week — 5 PSI wrong costs you 15+ minutes over 62 miles.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on Gravel Specific, Race Simulation, and Durability to prepare you for 62 miles of multi-surface chaos—rail trails to mud chutes in one race in Paris to Ancaster, Ontario, Canada.
